newsitem.title: UK: Elderly suffered most in Japanese quake - study.
newsitem.headline: Elderly suffered most in Japanese quake - study.

text.p: The 1995 earthquake that heavily damaged the Japanese city of Kobe hit the elderly especially hard, mostly because they were too shy to seek help, doctors reported on Friday.
More than 6,000 people died in the quake, most of them elderly, Noritoshi Tanida of the Hyogo College of Medicine reported in the British Medical Journal.
"More than half the fatalities were among those over 60 years old, and in this age group female fatalities were almost double those of men," he wrote.
The old suffered not only in the quake itself -- 77 percent of the fatalities were crushed to death -- but also from its after-effects, Tanida reported.
Although children and the elderly are usually cared for first after a disaster, the Hanshin earthquake was so devastating that society itself fell apart for a while, he said.
"The earthquake had destroyed local communities, and elderly people were left with no one they dared ask for help."
Their polite manners meant older people could be overlooked.
"Elderly people tended not to proclaim their problems unless they were questioned specifically," Tanida wrote.
"Elderly people restricted their own consumption of food and water, partly because they felt constrained to give way to younger people and partly because toilet facilities were scarce," he added.
He painted a sad picture of an older generation left completely bereft by the disaster.
"Suicide by elderly victims occurred at a rate of almost once a month. In addition, some elderly people were found dead in a ditch, presumably because they were lost in a new territory."
The next time a disaster hits, Tandia recommended, rescue workers should keep a special eye out for the elderly.
